node.title: Buyer Promises to Change Derogatory Name of Ski Resort Decades After Term Was Banned
node.description: "It's going to change. There is no doubt about that," said Perry Williams, who leads the group of investors purchasing the resort.

node.title: Inmate Whose Execution Was Halted Because of Vein Issue Dies 4 Years Later From Cancer
node.description: Doyle Lee Hamm was convicted in 1987 for the killing of hotel clerk Patrick Cunningham.

node.title: Pentagon to Analyze Positioning of Troops in Middle East, Asia-Pacific: Official
node.description: The study finished by the Pentagon and discussed by officials Monday revealed minor changes planned to be made regarding U.S. troop placements around the globe.

node.title: Journalist Danny Fenster Says Detroit Has Shown Him a Lot of Love Since He Returned Home
node.description: The journalist who was jailed in Myanmar for almost six months, was welcomed home as a candle lighter for a Detroit Hanukkah event.

node.title: Big final day ahead for Black Caps
node.description: The Black Caps face a tough final day of the first Test against India in Kanpur.

node.title: Chris Luxon front runner as National Party seeks saviour
node.description: Power Play - Some believe Luxon could have a better shot at uniting a caucus riven with distrust and resentment after its most recent bout of self-flagellation, writes Jane Patterson.

node.title: Free public transport could be life-changing for many, say campaigners
node.description: Alan Shaker believes if public transport was made free for tertiary students along with all community service card holders and those under 25, it would "level the playing field" for those in South…

node.title: 'It does put our community at risk': Locals oppose Rhythm and Vines
node.description: Gisborne locals say allowing music festival Rhythm and Vines to go ahead would be an open invitation for Covid-19 to arrive.

node.title: Labor board calls for new union election at Amazon Alabama warehouse
node.description: The order will give the nearly 6,000 workers at that facility a second chance to form a collective bargaining unit with the RWDSU.

node.title: New York officials recommend indoor mask wearing in response to Omicron
node.description: Residents are encouraged to wear masks in public and indoor settings where risk of spread is higher.

node.title: Who Is Parag Agrawal, Twitter’s New C.E.O.?
node.description: A longtime Twitter insider and a confidant of co-founder Jack Dorsey, Mr. Agrawal takes over as the social media company confronts various challenges.

node.title: Adolfo, Designer Who Dressed Nancy Reagan, Dies at 98
node.description: Adolfo, who began as a milliner and took inspiration from Chanel, was also a favorite of New York society women.

node.title: A judge temporarily blocks a vaccine mandate for health workers in 10 states.
node.description: The injunction is another setback for the Biden administration after an appeals court suspended its vaccine mandate for large employers earlier this month.

node.title: Biden Military Review Leaves Troops Where They Are, for Now
node.description: The report sidesteps a decision on what to do about troop numbers in Somalia, after President Donald J. Trump’s decision to pull out last year.

node.title: Fragmented Reactions Hinder Global Fight Against Omicron Variant
node.description: Almost two years into the pandemic, finger-pointing, lack of coordination, sparse information and fear are once again influencing policy.

node.title: Biden Commits to North Korea Peace as U.S., South Korea Talk End-of-War Declaration
node.description: "Once the ROK-U.S. consultation is completed, there will be ways to resolve such conditions through dialogue and consultations with the North," a South Korean Unification Ministry official told Newsweek.

node.title: Alabama Granting Parole Less Than Half as Often for Black Prisoners Compared to Whites
node.description: For the fiscal year that ended on September 30, 9 percent of Black inmates were granted parole while 23 percent of white inmates were approved.

node.title: Florida Top Draw for COVID-Weary Vacationers, Topping Pre-Pandemic Levels: Ron DeSantis
node.description: This year the state of Florida had 32.5 million travelers between July and September.  The advanced bookings for Orlando's holiday season are up 95% this year.

node.title: CDC Urging All Eligible Adults to Get COVID Booster in Light of Omicron Emergence
node.description: "Today, CDC is strengthening its recommendation on booster doses for individuals who are 18 years and older," the CDC declared in a statement.

node.title: Tennessee Education Dept. Rejects Complaint That MLK Book Is 'Anti-White Teaching'
node.description: The complaint pointed to a book showing photographs of segregated drinking fountains as violating the state law banning the teaching of critical race theory.

node.title: Where Americans are quitting their jobs at the highest rates
node.description: As the tight job market continues, some states have experienced an outsized jump in resignations.

node.title: In I.O.C.’s ‘Quiet Diplomacy,’ Critics See Whitewash of China’s Actions
node.description: The handling of the Peng Shuai case raised new questions about the I.O.C.’s relationship with China. One Olympic official called its actions ‘discreet.’ Critics called it collaboration.

node.title: Omicron carries scary mutations. That doesn’t mean they work well together.
node.description: Mutations can work together to make a virus more fearsome, but they can also cancel one another out. This phenomenon, called epistasis, is why scientists are reluctant to speculate on Omicron.

node.title: Finding Purpose by Giving Back
node.description: Whether helping people stay clean and safe, pursue their educational dreams or find the aid they need, volunteers make a difference.

node.title: Letter From Catherine the Great Shows Her Support for Inoculations
node.description: In a letter from 1787 to be sold at auction this week, the Russian empress called for widespread access to a precursor of the smallpox vaccine.

node.title: France Takes Steps to Curb Smuggling Across Channel After 27 Migrants Die Trying to Reach U.K.
node.description: Interior Minister Gerald Darmanin said justice officials and staff from the finance and foreign affairs ministries will join the agency to bolster it.

node.title: Prosecutors Ask SCOTUS to Review Bill Cosby Case, Say He Wasn't Granted Lifetime Immunity
node.description: Cosby was released in June after Pennsylvania's highest court ruled that an earlier promise not to prosecute the former comedian was binding.

node.title: U.S. Leaders Brace for Omicron as Inevitability, Urge Masks Indoors
node.description: As of Monday, more than a dozen countries around the world have reported cases of the Omicron variant, but the U.S. has yet to be included in that list.

node.title: KiwiSaver changes: What happens to your default fund from 1 December
node.description: Changes for default KiwiSaver funds coming into force on 1 December include a trimmed list of providers and default funds changing from conservative to balanced.

node.title: Fire and Emergency calls on the double vaccinated to fill volunteer firefighter void
node.description: Fire and Emergency is urging double-vaccinated people to train up as new volunteer firefighters to help fill a void created by the unvaccinated.
